AND NOT (X.R = X.Y),

* No. 3: The value for M

(X.M = 1).

This appears to be very similar to our first experiment, except that the values for S and O are missing.

The only work to do with this example is to write down No. 1 (a no-brainer), have No. 2 generated by AI, and think a bit to get X.M = 1 (no leading zeros!). After this, you see that the values for S, M, and O have been fixed in the simulation, and you just need to figure out what E has to be.

The effort is just the same as with the first experiment: AVC takes over the brainwork to get the values of S and O.

 And we already know that E = 5 does the trick:

 That's it! In case you're reading this right after publishing, have a great end of the year 2025, and an even better start into 2026!

entry.title: Custom Fields of type CodeList based on CDS Views in Analytical Apps: How to get text display option
entry.content:
Custom Fields of Type Code List based on CDS Views in Analytical Apps: How to get text display options  

Do you use a key user custom field of type ‚ÄúCode List based on CDS Views‚Äù in an analytical app like ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù? Did you ever wonder why only the code component of this custom field is shown? Do you also want to see the respective description field, as you (or other people) are not familiar with the code values? 

If your answer is yes, then this blog post is just for you. 

This blog post tells you what to do to make the description field available in analytical apps like the ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù app based on a concrete example.  
Please note that while we took an example from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition, it's basically the same for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition. 

Create a field of type ‚ÄúCode List based on CDS Views‚Äù and enable it for the analytical app  

Let‚Äôs assume you created a custom field ‚ÄúZZ1_EmployeeReference‚Äù of type ‚ÄúCode List based on CDS Views‚Äù for business context ‚ÄúFINS_JOURNAL_ENTRY_ITEM‚Äù (Accounting: Journal Entry Item). For your field you chose the standard SAP CDS view ‚ÄúI_WorkforcePerson‚Äù as value help view. To make your custom field available for the analytical app ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù you already enabled CDS query view ‚ÄúC_GLLINEITEMSQ0001‚Äù. With this, the underlying cube view ‚ÄúI_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE‚Äù was enabled for this field as well. 

Finding the relevant CDS view

You may wonder how to figure out that you need to enable CDS view ‚ÄúC_GLLINEITEMSQ0001‚Äù to make the field available for the Journal Entry Analyzer app. There are several ways to find that out: 

1. Using the Custom Fields app

Within the Custom Fields app, navigate to the detail screen of your custom field. Go to the ‚ÄúUser Interfaces‚Äù tab, select ‚ÄúAll‚Äù and enter ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù in the search field on the top right of the table showing the search results. One of the results is CDS view ‚ÄúC_GLLINEITEMSQ0001‚Äù.  
Note: this only works in case the descriptions for the respective objects involved provided by SAP are 100% consistent ‚Äì which is not always the case. 

2. Using the Fiori Apps Reference Library

You can use the Fiori Apps Reference Library as a more reliable and generic way to find out the name of the CDS view that you must enable to make the field available for the Journal Entry Analyzer app (and for any other analytical app).

Open the Fiori Apps Library and search for the app ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù.  You'll find this entry. Make sure to select the correct release on top of the page, which is ‚Äú2025 (Private Cloud)‚Äù in our case. 

On this page, select the ‚ÄúIMPLEMENTATION INFORMATION‚Äù tab and then navigate to the ‚ÄúConfiguration‚Äù section. Search for the ‚ÄúBex Query‚Äù entry. The ‚ÄúBex Query‚Äù entry states ‚Äú2CCFIGLLITMQ0001‚Äù.  
Note: the ‚ÄúBex Query‚Äù entry is only shown for analytical apps. 

When you remove the first two leading characters (‚Äú2C‚Äù), you get the name of the DDIC view (‚ÄúCFIGLLITMQ0001‚Äù) belonging to the respective CDS view that is exposed in this analytical application.  
Note: In this case, the Bex Query 2CCFIGLLITMQ0001 refers to CFIGLLITMQ0001, which is a classic DDIC view. Therefore, the CDS view name differs from the view name. For view entities, the names would be the same. 

 
Fiori Apps Reference Library entry of the app ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù 

To derive the CDS view name from the view name, you can open the view in ADT and find the name of the CDS view in the Data Definition property of this view. 

View CFIGLLITMQ0001 

Now that you know the name of the CDS view, you can: 

  1. navigate to the detail screen of your custom field within the Custom Fields app
  2. then, navigate to the ‚ÄúCDS view‚Äù tab
  3. in the search field, enter the name of this CDS view. The entry for the view will be shown and you can enable it

Make the custom field visible in the analytical app 

When you have published the custom field ‚ÄúZZ1_EmployeeReference‚Äù, the next step is to make it visible in the ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù app. To do this, open the app and populate the selection properties so that a list of entries is shown as soon as you press the ‚ÄúGo‚Äù button. 

In the ‚ÄúAvailable Fields‚Äù section, you'll now see the custom field ‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù. You can move it to the rows section by selecting the ‚ÄúAdd Field to column axis‚Äù option.
As soon as you've done that, the field becomes visible as an additional row on the right side of the screen. 
Right-click on the column header of the additional row of the ‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù field and select "Display". The pop-up shows options such as  

  • ‚ÄúID only‚Äù 
  • ‚ÄúDescription only‚Äù 
  • ‚ÄúID and description‚Äù 
  • ‚ÄúDescription and ID‚Äù 

These display options allow you to show the description belonging to the code value of the ‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù field. In our case, none of these options is available (see screenshot below). 

‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù custom field as column in analytical app: no text display options available 

How to get the text display options

To make the missing text display options available, go to the Custom Fields app and navigate to the detail screen of your custom field. In the General tab, you'll find a slider button called ‚ÄúAnalytical Support‚Äù. Choosing this button, an addition field is displayed called ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù. Here, you can enter the master data view which is used for this field in analytical apps (like the ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù app). In our case, it's prefilled with ‚ÄúI_WorkforcePerson‚Äù, which is the same CDS view we had already chosen as value help view (see screenshot below). Note that there is also a dedicated value help view called ‚ÄúI_WorkforcePersonVH‚Äù, which would be even more suitable for use as ‚ÄúValue Help View‚Äù. 

‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù custom field: activating Analytical Support and choosing Master Data View 

Prefilling the ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù is the default behavior of the Custom Fields app in cases where the value help view fulfills all the requirements of an analytical master data view. The view must have the header annotation ‚Äú@Analytics.dataCategory: #DIMENSION‚Äù. Please note that within the value help for the ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù, only CDS views that fulfill this criterion are shown. 
Go ahead and save and publish the custom field again. Next, reload the ‚ÄúJournal Entry Analyzer‚Äù app. Click on the column header of the ‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù custom field to see that all of the four text display options are displayed. These allow you to configure whether and how the description should be displayed (see screenshot below). 

‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù custom field as column in analytical app: text display options available 

With this, you are done. Congratulations! 

Technical details

In case you are interested in the technical details, let me shortly explain what you have changed by selecting a ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù for your custom field ‚ÄúEmployee Reference‚Äù: 

Before selecting a master data view, the CDS extension that had been generated for the custom field "Employee Reference" for the cube view "I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE" underneath the query view  "C_GLLINEITEMSQ0001" looked like this: 

CDS Extend on cube view I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE before setting the ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù on the custom field 

After specifying the master data view and publishing the field again, the CDS extension looks like this: 

CDS Extend on cube view I_GLACCOUNTLINEITEMCUBE after setting the ‚ÄúMaster Data View‚Äù on the custom field 

The difference lies within the foreign key association and the respective foreign key association annotation marked in red. The analytics infrastructure needs this metadata to provide the text field.  
You may wonder how the analytics infrastructure knew which field in the ‚ÄúMeta Data View‚Äù I_WORKFORCEPERSON is the text field. This is derived from the annotation ObjectModel.text.element: 'PersonFullName' of the key field in ‚ÄúMeta Data View‚Äù I_WORKFORCEPERSON.  

Feedback, Comments, or Questions: 

You‚Äôre cordially invited to provide them in the comments section below. Please follow our profiles to get updates when we publish more posts on these topics. 
Feel invited to post and answer questions here (https://answers.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26) and read other posts on the topic (https://blogs.sap.com/tags/270c4f37-c335-46e1-bfad-a256637d5e26/). 

I want to thank‚ÄØYasmina van Rooij‚ÄØ(YasminavanRooij) and Karsten Schaser (Karsten_Schaser) for their extremely helpful contributions.

entry.title: SAP Central Business Configuration Best Practices During SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition Upgrades
entry.content:
With SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, customers benefit from regular upgrades and updates that bring the latest innovations, enhanced security, and improved performance. With SAP Central Business Configuration serving as the single entry point for scoping, organizational structures, and configuration activities, it is natural that upgrade cycles involve certain considerations within SAP Central Business Configuration.

Why Protective Measures Matter During Upgrades

Think of these measures as the safety rails on your system. By locking down critical operations (transports, data migrations, extensibility) during upgrade windows, SAP ensures the upgrade process can run smoothly without unintended side effects ‚àí protecting the system from half-done changes or version mismatches.

With SAP rolling out major upgrades twice a year (typically in February and August) and regular updates (hotfix collections) every two weeks between major upgrades, having a clear restriction schedule allows customers to adopt innovations in a controlled, manageable way. For more information on the schedule, please refer to:

  • Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-System Landscape
  • Upgrade & Maintenance Schedule for SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 2-System Landscape

Protective Measures and Best Practices

  • Keep your team well informed about upcoming upgrade cycles.
  • Avoid initial activation around upgrade time, as it‚Äôs typically time consuming.
  • Avoid large deploymentsto prevent stuck deployments or partial content activation.
  • Perform business configuration activities until 8 hours before system downtime.
  • Make changes to your scope or organizational structure up until the content upgrade begins.
  • For the parallel line, avoid initiating rebase and merge before the upgrade starts, as these actions lock the workspace.
  • Avoid scheduling critical go-lives and User Acceptance Testing (UAT) around upgrades.
  • For the 2-system landscape, in addition to the above, avoid releasing transport requests from the quality system to the production system.

SAP Central Business Configuration Impacts

Let‚Äôs look at how the SAP Central Business Configuration system behaves during these system upgrades.

1. During Update: Here‚Äôs the update maintenance schedule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape:

Update windows and time of workspace locking per region

  • Please note that deployments are automatically locked 12 hours before the software update starts, aligning with the timing of the Major Upgrade Window (MUW).
  • Business configuration activities can be performed until the system enters downtime.
  • Organizational structure updates, scope extensions, and new country activations are allowed until the content update begins and the SAP Central Business Configuration workspace becomes locked. 

2. During Upgrade: Here‚Äôs the upgrade maintenance schedule for the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, 3-system landscape:

This blog provides a summary of the apps and their functions required to file GSTR-6 in SAP S/4HANA Cloud (formerly known as SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition).

GSTR-6 is the mandatory monthly return for an Input Service Distributor (ISD),  a critical compliance piece for large enterprises with centralized procurement, such as software companies with multiple offices under the same PAN. The ISD mechanism allows the Head Office to receive input service invoices (like consulting or software licenses) centrally and then distribute the associated Input Tax Credit (ITC) to the unit locations where the services are actually consumed.

The SAP S/4HANA system manages this distribution automatically through ISD program known as J1IG_ISDN . It calculates how much of the total ITC each branch should get. This calculation is usually based on a fair measure, like the turnover (sales) of each branch relative to the others and maintained in configuration settings.

SAP generates special internal documents (ISD invoices) that formally transfer the tax credit to each branch. This allows the individual branches to legally reduce their own tax bill by the credit they received.

entry.title: Electronic Invoicing Italian Mandate: a practical how to guide
entry.content:
Introduction: The Digital Mandate

Companies operating in Italy face a significant challenge complying with the Italian electronic invoicing mandate. This article serves as a practical guide, breaking down the SAP Public Cloud solution into three core pillars: XML file creation, Italian tax authority (SDI) connection, and digital signature activation.

1.  Creating the XML file

With the introduction of the electronic invoicing, the only invoice format legally recognized is the XML . The paper format can be added as attachment but its content is not considered by the Italian Tax Authority.  

SAP's solution covers the main business processes required to generate these XML files, including FI invoices, SD invoices, convergent invoices, and settlement documents. All of these are managed through the E-document cockpit. The crucial step in this stage is the XML file mapping, which involves translating a company's internal SAP data into the official tags required by the tax authority's XML format. SAP provides standard logic to handle many of these mandatory data points automatically. These standard logical are based on SAP Best Practices, documented in SAP Help Portal at process detail.

2. Establishing the SDI Connection (Italian Tax Authority)

Establishing the connection to the Italian tax authority's platform, the Sistema di Interscambio (SDI), is the most crucial step of the implementation. This phase requires attention and precision to avoid issues that often require a lot of time to be solved. For S/4HANA Cloud solutions (both public and private), SAP provides a direct, individual connection to the SDI, without any third-party providers. Successfully completing this process results in the company receiving its own official SDI recipient code from the tax authority, which must then be shared with all suppliers.  To facilitate this complex process, SAP provides a a step-by-step guide from planning to final configuration within SAP  Discovery Center Mission where customers can have access to the end to end detailed and documented process (including all OSS Notes and SAP official guides linked) . After the creation of Certificates (both client and server) and Custom Domain (to ensure a safer connection between your private system and the public tax authority platform) that are fundamental for the connection set up,  the SDI requires to pass Interoperability Test to confirm the registration and officially test the connection and switch the channel from test to production. Interoperability Test are done via FatturaPa portal (the official portal of the Italian Tax Authority) and practically consists of creating some invoicing respecting he scenarios required by SDI and using the list of "Codici Destinatario" provided by SDI in the FatturaPA Portal. An expert tip for ensuring these tests are accepted is to use the external document type TD20 (self-invoices). Because the sender and receiver VAT numbers are the same during this test, using the self-invoice type prevents rejections and helps secure the "green light" needed to proceed.

 

3. Activating  the Digital Signature

The last mile of the SDI connection is the activation of the digital signature. This requirements is mandatory for all B2G invoices even though can be used for all invoices regardless the recipient. 

SAP's standard solution includes an integrated digital signature service provided by Aruba, an official Italian provider. Once configured, the process is fully automated. When the system detects a B2G invoice, it is submitted for digital signature before being sent to the SDI.  Activating this service requires filling out a form with customer details and sending it to a dedicated SAP email address, which then forwards the request to Aruba to initiate the process.

All details, updated forms, procedure and addresses are available in SAP  Discovery Center Mission within the dedicated step.

To get more and detailed information about this core process, a dedicated enablement session has been recorded, both in Italian and English language.  You can find all in SAP Workzone.

I kindly suggest all customers and partner to have a look on that to check the end to end process and. download the documentation that is essential to complete this journey and activate the mandate.

entry.title: Modernize Planning: Universal Hierarchy in SAP Revenue Growth Management for SAP Cloud ERP Customers
entry.content:
1. Navigating Hierarchy Complexity

For emerging consumer products companies, managing customer and product hierarchies is a fundamental challenge for commercial planning. This complexity is inherent to the fast-moving industry, where product portfolios evolve with new launches and discontinuations, customer organizations restructure, and planning cycles need to align with diverse retailer calendars. System administrators and Key Account Managers (KAMs) alike face the challenge of ensuring data consistency, planning accuracy, and operational efficiency amidst these changes. Traditional approaches often lead to manual, error-prone adjustments and a constant game of catch-up.

For customers adopting SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, the introduction of the Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management addresses these pain points, offering a time-aware, unified, and streamlined approach to hierarchy management.

 

2. Universal Hierarchy Framework: A Future-Proof Foundation for Revenue Growth

SAP Revenue Growth Management is designed to empower CPG companies with robust tools for account planning, promotion management, and analytics. A critical capability for customers of SAP Cloud ERP is the Universal Hierarchy Framework. We now support both customer and product hierarchies that are time-dependent and versioned‚Äîcapable of consuming SAP Public Cloud's Universal Hierarchy Framework. This means customers now have a future-proof way to manage hierarchies, transforming them as time-aware assets for promotion planning and execution.

For more information on our current capabilities, see An Overview of SAP Revenue Growth Management. 

 

3. Key Functionalities of Universal Hierarchy Framework in SAP Revenue Growth Management

3.1. Plan Ahead with Confidence: Time-Dependent Hierarchies

The ability to plan hierarchy changes in advance is a foundational benefit of the Universal Hierarchy Framework provided by SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, which SAP Revenue Growth Management now supports. Unlike traditional hierarchies where updates take effect immediately, the Universal Hierarchy Framework allows system admins or KAMs to define validity periods for both customer and product hierarchies. This means users can plan and schedule entire hierarchy changes‚Äîsuch as a sales region reorganization or a new product category introduction‚Äîwell in advance, with changes becoming effective automatically on a specified date.

  • Proactive Workflow Alignment

According to user research, portfolio reviews and hierarchy changes are typically planned months in advance. With the Universal Hierarchy Framework, users can set up all necessary changes far in advance for the next planning year‚Äîand avoid end-of-year rushes before the holiday season, directly aligning system updates with strategic business cycles.

  • Reduced Operational Risk

By allowing changes to be scheduled and automatically activated, system admins and KAMs significantly reduce the risk of errors or missed updates during critical periods, ensuring that planning and execution always reflect the intended future organizational reality.

 

3.2. Unified View: Managing Multi‚ÄëVersion Product Hierarchies in a Single Screen

Businesses rarely operate on a single, fixed product hierarchy version for a long period of time. The Universal Hierarchy Framework recognizes this reality by supporting multiple time‚Äëbound product hierarchy versions. SAP Revenue Growth Management introduces a unified view ‚Äî a one‚Äëscreen user experience that presents all relevant hierarchy versions on a single screen. This allows KAMs to view and select products or categories across different hierarchy versions without switching contexts, ensuring a complete and continuous planning overview.

One-Screen Transparency

  • Workflow: For example, in a 2026 ready meals account plan, ‚Äúsalad‚Äù belongs to product hierarchy A (PH A) in the first half of the year, and ‚Äúpizza‚Äù is introduced in the latter half under product hierarchy B (PH B). When a KAM plans a promotion for both items, they need to access them on one screen.
  • A Unified View: By default, the UI primarily displays the earliest valid hierarchy version (e.g. PH A) for the selected planning period. Users are notified that multiple hierarchy versions are available and can switch between versions on the same page. This one-screen view, validated by user research, reduces navigation effort and prevents confusion associated with managing disjointed views.

Uninterrupted Focus for Informed Business Decisions

  • Workflow: If a KAM views PH B, which excludes "salad", they can still find "salad" in the Product Categories in the Other Versions section. When the KAM selects ‚Äúsalad‚Äù and switches to PH A where "salad" exists, the UI keeps the selection valid, allowing planning to continue without interruption.
  • Informed Decision-Making: KAMs can identify changes and understand where products sit in the hierarchy structure during a given planning period, providing valuable context for business decisions.
  • Uninterrupted Planning: Product selection remains valid when switching between versions, reducing toggling and keeping KAMs focused on planning tasks.

 

3.3. Streamlined Selection: The Fully Expanded Flat List

When users need speed and efficiency‚Äîespecially for customer selection‚Äîa flat list that presents all available options at a single, non-nested level, is often more effective than a tree structure. In SAP Revenue Growth Management, customer selection uses a fully expanded flat list to speed search and selection.

  • Quick, Effortless Navigation

KAMs looking for a specific customer no longer need to drill down through multiple tree structures. In promotion planning, choosing correct customers quickly is often more critical than understanding the full customer tree. With the flat list, KAMs can search, filter, select, and continue‚Äîkeeping focus on core planning objectives. This simplification is backed by user research and aligns with natural user behavior.

  • All Options Expanded at Fingertips

Within SAP Revenue Growth Management, flat lists are presented fully expanded by default, enabling users to see all selectable items at once. This creates a simple, efficient experience and is accompanied by search and filter capabilities for productivity.

 

4. Co-Innovation: Shape Universal Hierarchy Management

The introduction of Universal Hierarchy Framework is a significant step in enabling customers on SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition to utilize SAP Revenue Growth Management. By providing time-dependent hierarchies, unified multi-version views, and streamlined selection experiences, we aim to help emerging small and medium-sized companies in the consumer product industry to stay agile and competitive in a rapidly changing market.

If you're an existing or a prospective customer of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition, you're more than welcome to join our co-innovation for Universal Hierarchies. Contact us today at RGM_Engage@sap.com to start the journey toward modernizing your trade promotion management and embracing a more agile approach to planning.

 

Final Note: The support for Universal Hierarchies in SAP Revenue Growth Management is scheduled to become available with the SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition 2602 release. Secure your spot as a co-innovation partner today and let‚Äôs drive your revenue growth.

entry.title: Customizing the Company Profitability Review Booklet in Margin Analysis
entry.content:
Motivation

In my previous blog I explained the Review Booklet (Template) In Margin Analysis For Company Profitability Reporting and when it needs adjustment by customers.

In this blog I will explain how to copy and adjust the underlying analytical queries and adjust the selection to prepare them for a customized review booklet. It is for key users and technical consultants.

Since we did enhancements in the booklet with SAP Cloud ERP 2602, as announced in the previous blog, we had to create new analytical queries, which I will already use in my screenshots. I recommend to wait for 2602 to do the adjustments, so you already have the new features for several company codes and currencies in your customized booklet.

Copying the SAP delivered queries

Launch the App ‚ÄúCustom Analytical Queries and Services‚Äù (F1572A) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST. Click on the link ‚ÄúManage Queries‚Äù. In the next screen click the button ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù.

Figure 1: Copy the first SAP delivered query 

In the pop-up, name your custom query, e.g. ‚ÄúYY1_CUSTCOMPMARG‚Äù and as the source query specify ‚ÄúC_COMPANYMARGINQUERY_2‚Äù (for 2602 release, in 2508 it would be C_COMPANYMARGINQUERY).

This query is used on the ‚ÄúCompany Margin (Full Year)‚Äù page group of the booklet.

Click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù and on the next screen give your new customer query a name, e.g. ‚ÄúCompany Margin Custom Query‚Äù.

Figure 2: Name custom query

 Then click on the ‚ÄúFields‚Äù tab.

Figure 3: Optionally add a remove fields

Here you can optionally add or remove fields in the query to be used or not in the booklet.

The list of available fields comes from the underlying cube I_CompanyMarginCube_2 (in 2602, or I_CompanyMarginCube in 2508) and can only be changed by SAP.

If you also want the ‚ÄúYear-to-Date‚Äù, ‚ÄúFiscal Quarter‚Äù or ‚ÄúFiscal Period‚Äù comparison page groups, which are available in the SAP delivered booklet, in you customized booklet, please repeat the steps above for the SAP delivered query ‚ÄúC_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY_2‚Äù (in 2602, or C_COMARGPERDCOMPARISONQRY in 2508) after completing the following steps for the first query.

 

Figure 4: Copy the second SAP delivered query 

 

Adjusting the selection criteria in the custom query

Next click on the tab ‚ÄúModel‚Äù. You will see the list of measures (or key figures) used in the booklet.

As explained in the previous blog, you need to adjust the selection of Read Key Figures, if you do not use the SAP best practices Functional Areas.

But let‚Äôs first see the usage of the semantic tags on the Read Key Figures.

Select e.g. the measure ‚ÄúBilled Revenue (technical name ‚ÄúBilledRevenueAmntInDispCrry‚Äù). Then turn on ‚ÄúSematic Tag‚Äù selection criteria. 

Figure 5: Sematic Tag selection of Read Key Figure

 You will see, that the semantic tag ‚ÄúBILL_REV‚Äù is used to read billed revenues. Please do not change this.

Now you can go through the list of Read Key Figures to decide, where the Functional Area selection needs to be adjusted.

Figure 6: List of calculated and read key figures with selection criteria

 As an example, let‚Äôs take ‚ÄúCost of Goods Sold ‚Äì Variable‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúVariableCOGSAmntInDispCrry‚Äù). Select the measure from the list and activate ‚ÄúFunctional Area‚Äù selection criteria. 

Figure 7: Change Functional Area selection for COGS

 You see the SAP best practices Functional Areas YB18 (Cost of Goods Sold) and YB25 (Consulting/Services) are used to read COGS for product or service centric business processes.

You can now change them to the ones you use in your respective sales scenarios.

Figure 8: Add Functional Area selection

 The same applies for the measure ‚ÄúCost of Goods Sold ‚Äì Fixed‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúFxdCOGSAmtInDspCrcy‚Äù.

 As another example let‚Äôs take the measure ‚ÄúAdministration Overhead‚Äù (technical name ‚ÄúAdminOverheadAmtInDspCrcy‚Äù).

In the SAP delivered query the Functional Area YB40 is used for Administration. You can now replace with your own.

Figure 9: Replace Functional Area selection

Please complete this task for all measures, which need adjustment of Functional Area.

If you have copied the query for the period comparison pages, please do the same there. It contains the same measure structure.

 

Optional: Change default values for filters and parameters

The query also contains same default values for general selection in the booklet. You can optionally change them, so the apply for all users in your customized booklet.

For example, if you want to use your own Financial Statement Version (please see previous blog), go on the tab ‚ÄúParameters‚Äù, select the ‚ÄúFinancial Statement Version‚Äù and change the default value. 

Figure 10: Change default values of parameters

 Please note, that the FSV can stay a filter in the booklet and can later be changed by an end user again.

 Another example is to change the default value of the global filter ‚ÄúCurrency Field‚Äù, which is introduced in 2602.

Go on the tab ‚ÄúFilter‚Äù and select ‚ÄúCurrency Field‚Äù. The default value is Company Code Currency (CCC). You can change e.g. to Global Currency (GC).

Figure 11: Change default values of filters 

 

Check and publish your custom queries

In the next step please go to the tab ‚ÄúLogs‚Äù and click the button ‚ÄúCheck‚Äù.

No errors should appear in the logs and you can click ‚ÄúPublish‚Äù.

Figure 12: Publish custom query

 Please repeat for second query.

 

Create InA Service with both customer queries

The custom booklet will require an InA Service which contain the custom queries.

To create it, go back to the start page of the App ‚ÄúCustom Analytical Queries and Services‚Äù (F1572A) and click ‚ÄúManage InA Services‚Äù, then click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù.

Figure 13: Create custom InA Service

 Give it a name, a label and click ‚ÄúOK‚Äù.

Next add your custom queries to it with ‚ÄúAdd query‚Äù and publish the service. 

Figure 14: Add custom queries

 

Create custom review booklet

You can now create your own review booklet based on the InA Service.

Please launch the App ‚ÄúManage KPIs and Reports‚Äù (F2814) with a user having the role SAP_BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.

Select the tab ‚ÄúReview Booklets‚Äù and click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù. 

Figure 15: Create review booklet.

Give it an ID, a name and description and click ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù. 

Figure 16: Open configuration for custom review booklet

 Now click ‚ÄúOpen Configuration‚Äù to access the review booklet designer. On the tab ‚ÄúGeneral‚Äù specify your custom Ina Service. 

Figure 17: Add custom Ina Service in custom review booklet

 Then click ‚ÄúGenerate Content‚Äù, select your custom queries and click ‚ÄúGenerate‚Äù. 

Figure 18: Generate booklet content for customer queries

This will prepare the data providers for the booklet.

You now can go through the booklet designer and customize your pages groups, pages, row and column sets, etc.

Please see the SAP help how to work with the review booklet designer: Configuring a Review Booklet

This is a manual step, which can‚Äôt be avoided by coping the SAP delivered review booklet, since all settings in the review booklet designer depend on the used queries.

You can however have a look at the SAP delivered booklet as a reference how to configure yours.

Figure 19: Reference Business Pages in SAP delivered booklet

 

Conclusion

You now know, how to customize a query and create a custom review booklet on top of it.

With this know-how you can also customize other SAP delivered review booklets.

The article can also give you an idea, how to create your complete own custom analytical queries, using developer extensibility. This is more advanced and would allow you to create an own contribution margin structure with more than 3 levels and different key figures for revenues and costs.

You can also create review booklet on top of self-developed custom analytical queries.
